repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Rural Finance Technical Assistance
            and Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Implementation Completion Note is
            for the Rural Finance Technical Assistance and Pilot
            Project, which became effective on January 14, 1998 and was
            cancelled on December 15, 1999. Out of a total of US$30
            million, $1.3 million was disbursed. Timing was decisive
            factor in the cancellation of this project. In December
            1994, responding to sizable outflows of capital, the
            government allowed the peso to float, resulting in a
            maxi-devaluation of the currency. The combination of a major
            devaluation and a sharp contraction of liquidity of banking
            system severely compromised the financial position of many
            intermediaries. Cancellation was also influenced by an
            internal debate within the government and the Technical
            Committee regarding the transfer of the Rural Finance
            Markets Development Fund and the General Directorate for
            Development Banks to another agency. The lessons learned
            include: a) The success of a rural financial markets project
            that operates through the formal banking sector requires a
            healthy financial and banking sector. b) Good diagnostic
            work can facilitate the policy dialogue as well as the
            preparation of the project. c) In the case of experimental
            projects, design needs to emphasize flexibility. d) Analysis
            of external factors during loan preparation can prevent
            subsequent disappointments during implementation. e)
            Borrower ownership and inclusion of other stakeholders are critical.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Rural Finance Technical Assistance
            and Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Rural Finance
            Technical Assistance and Pilot Project are to augment the
            participation of rural entrepreneurs in rural financial
            markets, specifically of the poor; overcome the segmentation
            of these markets; and increase competition in the sector.
            The project will consist of two components: a) direct
            technical assistance which will support Ministry of Finance
            (SHCP) policy making and dialogue by financing expenditures
            (more specifically the component will finance the provision
            training and technical assistance as well as carrying out
            studies in support of initiatives designed to improve the
            performance of rural financial markets in Mexico); and b)
            pilot experimentation with financial technologies and
            financing; this will support the development and testing of
            appropriate technologies of financial intermediation in
            rural areas and the experimentation with innovative policies
            by disbursing against incremental expenditures incurred.

Mexico - Rural Finance Technical Assistance
